G.  E.  F.  Chilver
resources at the time,  if not also of his attitude towards the Roman stitution. 
The belief that the powers continued to be triumviral in character does not necessarily depend upon one view rather than another of the date on which the second term of the triumvirate was due to expire.  Mommsen's doctrine that triumviral powers were of the type which in certain stances could be continued after the terminal date was combined with the contention that in this case the date was 31 December 33 : the most recent supporter of the former doctrine was W.  Kolbe who remained a firm believer in 31 December 32.  But on the latter point Kolbe brought no new evidence to bear,  and some may feel that the most cogent arguments on either side of this irritating question are neither those which appealed to him nor those which he attempted to refute.  The Trieste inscription { ILS^ 77 ) was long ago shown to be inconclusive since Octavian would have been described as »cos.  desig.  tert.  « in 33 as well as in 32® ; nor are the words »finito triumviratus tempore « in the Livian Epitomator ^ decisive for the view opposed to Kolbe's,  since Livy himself may have been describing an alleged utterance of Antonius about a situation still in the future or about an attempt to terminate his powers »ante tempus «.  But it is surprising that Kolbe failed to enlist in his favour the argument supplied by U.  WilckenS.  At Misenum in 39 consuls were nominated for all the years ending in 31,  when Octavian and Antonius were to hold office jointly,  and when,  it seemed to Appian's source®,  they might resign their To this argument the reply of T.  Rice Holmes was inadequate It is true that in 39 the très vir г did not know how long their second term would last,  since the second term was not fixed until two years later.  But it still remains odd that in 37 the two,  who by then did know about their own lists of consuls,  should deliberately have agreed to terminate their power when Cn.  Domitius was starting his consulate instead of at the beginning of their own joint year
Can we then explain the words of the Res Gestae^ in which Augustus states that he was triumvir avvéxeaiv ëxeoiv ôéxoc?  These certainly seem to take us no further than the end of 3 3,  whether for the theoretical or for the

7.  To Book CXXXII.  Schönbauet 33 ff. ,  reminds us that the context appears to be one when war has already begun. 
8.  Sb,  à.  preuss,  Akad.  d,  Wissenschaften ( 1925 ),  68ff. 
9.  Appian,  В.  е. ,  V.  313. 
ig.  op,  dt, ,  241 ff. 
II,  In Camb,  Anc,  Hist. ,  X ( 1934 ),  42 n.  1.  it is suggested that it was Appian's knowledge of the consular lists which misled him in Illyrica,  28.  But if this was his ference it was a tempting one.

label: Augustus and the Roman Constitution 1939 - 1950
